title: Makerbot lawsuits pile up as parent company stock continues 10-month skid
text:
See All Homes of the Day More than just a product issue though, the suit also alleges the defendants “engaged in a fraudulent scheme to artificially inflate the company’s stock price by both misrepresenting and concealing the true operational and conditions of the Company and its indirect, wholly owned subsidiary, MakerBot Industries, LLC (“MakerBot”).” Leading up to the alleged scheme, Minnesota-based Stratasys (Nasdaq: SSYS) purchased Makerbot for $493.7 million in August 2013, at a time when the stock was worth about $90. Between then and January 3, the stock jumped 33 percent to its all-time high of $136. But between September 2014 and now, the stock dropped 73 percent — bottoming out at today’s midday trading price of $34.49. In February, mid-way through that slide, Robbins Geller Rudman & Dowd LLP filed a class action lawsuit against Stratasys claiming that it mislead investors about details pertaining to the Makerbot acquisition, according to a 3D Print report . A month later Makerbot closed three retail shops and laid off 20 percent of its staff, or about 100 workers. During the struggles Stratasys seems committed to its investment in Makerbot. In June it announced plans to expand its subsidiary into Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Beijing and earlier this month it announced a deal that will put Makerbot machines in each of the more than 600 Sam's Clubs nation wide. The plaintiffs have demanded a trial by jury, though no date has been set.
